unnormalised: Planning a trip by train in India? It can be an adventure! Indian Railways is massive – we're talking 1000s of trains crisscrossing the country. Navigating it all can feel a bit daunting at first, especially if you're used to the trains abroad. So, let's break it down, shall we?
normalised: Planning a trip by train in India? It can be an adventure! Indian Railways is massive – we are talking thousands of trains crisscrossing the country. Navigating it all can feel a bit daunting at first, especially if you are used to the trains abroad. So, let us break it down, shall we?

unnormalised: First things first: booking tickets. IRCTC, that’s the Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation, is your go-to website and app. Trains like the Rajdhani Exp, or the Duronto, are super popular and booking opens 120 days in advance, so prepone your planning! Keep an eye on tatkal tickets if you're booking closer to the travel date. These open one day prior at 10:00 AM for AC classes and 11:00 AM for non-AC. Set those alarms!
normalised: First things first: booking tickets. I-R-C-T-C, that is the Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation, is your go-to website and app. Trains like the Rajdhani Exp, or the Duronto, are super popular and booking opens one hundred and twenty days in advance, so prepone your planning! Keep an eye on tatkal tickets if you are booking closer to the travel date. These open one day prior at ten a-m for A-C classes and eleven a-m for non-A-C. Set those alarms!

unnormalised: Then you’ve got different classes. 1A is the top-notch AC First Class, followed by 2A and 3A (two-tier and three-tier AC). Then there's Sleeper class (SL), which is non-AC and packed, but a true Indian experience! General class is even more basic, often unreserved, and can get seriously crowded. Choosing your class depends on your budget and comfort level, really.
normalised: Then you have got different classes. One-A is the top-notch A-C First Class, followed by Two-A and Three-A (two-tier and three-tier A-C). Then there is Sleeper class (S-L), which is non-A-C and packed, but a true Indian experience! General class is even more basic, often unreserved, and can get seriously crowded. Choosing your class depends on your budget and comfort level, really.

unnormalised: Let's talk about the actual travel. The PNR number (Passenger Name Record) – that's your key to everything. Check your PNR status online to see if your ticket's confirmed. Train schedules can be a bit…fluid. Use the NTES app (National Train Enquiry System) to track your train in real-time. It will show you if your train is late, say by 2 hrs, or running on time.
normalised: Let us talk about the actual travel. The P-N-R number (Passenger Name Record) – that is your key to everything. Check your P-N-R status online to see if your ticket is confirmed. Train schedules can be a bit…fluid. Use the N-T-E-S app (National Train Enquiry System) to track your train in real-time. It will show you if your train is late, say by two hours, or running on time.

unnormalised: Food on trains is a whole other story! You can order meals online through IRCTC e-catering, or rely on the vendors hopping on and off at stations selling everything from chai to biryani. Pro tip: try the local snacks at the stations; it's part of the experience! Stations like New Delhi Rly Stn, or Chennai Central, have food stalls aplenty.

unnormalised: What about luggage? There are restrictions, of course. For AC classes, it's typically around 50 kg, and for Sleeper, it's around 40 kg. Excess luggage? You’ll have to pay extra at the luggage office.
normalised: What about luggage? There are restrictions, of course. For A-C classes, it is typically around fifty kilogram, and for Sleeper, it is around forty kilogram. Excess luggage? You will have to pay extra at the luggage office.

unnormalised: And finally, a word on safety. Keep an eye on your belongings, especially during overnight journeys. Also, be aware of your surroundings. Indian Railways, while a lifeline for millions, can be chaotic. Trust your instincts, and you'll have a memorable journey. Remember that train #12345 from Mumbai to Delhi usually arrives on time, but things happen. Safe travels!
